Literature Review: The study of security regimes has become an increasingly important area of research in anthropology, with scholars making significant contributions to our understanding of how security is conceptualized, implemented, and experienced across various contexts. This literature review examines the key theoretical and methodological contributions that anthropologists have made to the study of security regimes, with a particular focus on transnational and imperial entanglements.Anthropologists have played a crucial role in denaturalizing discourses of security, challenging the notion that security is a neutral or objective concept. Goldstein's (2010) work on 'securitization theory' has been particularly influential in this regard, demonstrating how security is socially constructed and often used to justify exceptional measures and the expansion of state power. Building on this, Masco (2014) has explored how the concept of national security has been mobilized in the United States to reshape political and social life, arguing that it has become a powerful tool for managing public affect and justifying state interventions.While much of the existing literature on security regimes has focused on the masculinist frontlines and visibly spectacular instances of state power, recent anthropological work has sought to expand our understanding of where security regimes operate and how they are constituted. Amar (2013) has made significant contributions in this area, examining how security regimes are enacted through everyday practices and interactions, particularly in urban spaces. His work highlights the importance of considering the micro-level processes through which security is produced and contested.Adopting a transnational feminist lens, scholars have begun to rethink the sites and technologies through which security regimes are constituted, expanded, and challenged. Grewal (2017) has been at the forefront of this approach, examining how security discourses intersect with gender, race, and nationalism in the context of the global war on terror. Her work demonstrates how security regimes operate not only at the level of the state but also through intimate spaces such as the home and family.The role of affect and emotion in the constitution of security regimes has also received increasing attention from anthropologists. Ochs (2011) has explored how fear and anxiety are mobilized in the production of security discourses and practices, while Lutz (2009) has examined the emotional dimensions of militarization and its impact on everyday life. These studies highlight the importance of considering the affective dimensions of security regimes and how they shape individual and collective experiences.Anthropologists have also made significant contributions to our understanding of the racial and gendered dimensions of security regimes. Das and Poole (2004) have explored how security practices often reinforce and reproduce racial hierarchies, while Ticktin (2011) has examined how humanitarian interventions in the name of security can perpetuate gendered and racialized forms of violence. These studies underscore the importance of intersectional approaches in analyzing security regimes and their effects.The transnational and imperial entanglements of security regimes have been a key focus of recent anthropological work. Ferguson and Gupta (2002) have examined how neoliberal governance and security practices are intertwined in the context of globalization, while Fassin (2011) has explored the humanitarian dimensions of border security and immigration control. These studies highlight the complex ways in which security regimes operate across national boundaries and are implicated in broader processes of global governance.Methodologically, anthropologists studying security regimes have faced unique challenges due to the often secretive and sensitive nature of their research subjects. Gusterson (1996) has been influential in developing approaches to studying 'closed' communities, such as nuclear weapons scientists, while Sluka (2000) has explored the ethical and practical challenges of conducting fieldwork in conflict zones. These contributions have been crucial in developing methodologies for studying security regimes in diverse contexts.The changing profile of researchers studying security regimes has also raised important methodological and ethical questions. As Visweswaran (1994) has argued, the positionality of the researcher, including their race, gender, nationality, and class, can significantly impact the research process and outcomes. This is particularly relevant in the study of security regimes, where issues of access, trust, and power dynamics are often heightened.In conclusion, anthropological research on security regimes has made significant contributions to our understanding of how security is conceptualized, implemented, and experienced across various contexts. By adopting transnational feminist lenses and expanding the sites and technologies through which security regimes are examined, anthropologists have challenged and enriched traditional approaches to security studies. As the field continues to evolve, addressing the methodological and ethical challenges associated with studying security regimes will be crucial for advancing our understanding of these complex and often contentious phenomena.
